title: Is student life all good?
intro: Leaving home to start life at university is an exciting time for many young people but very challenging for some. Alice and Neil discuss the psychological pressures of making this big transition. They also teach some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: In a survey of students at Imperial College London, how many students said they suffered from high levels of stress or a mental health condition during their time at college? Was it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: seeing a situation as better than it really was
being in a situation that you aren't familiar with and which makes you feel nervous
professional help with personal or psychological problems
missing your family and friends when you're away from home
pressure or worry caused by a difficult situation
where you try to give your attention to two or more things at the same time
be responsible for or take care of yourself
planning how much money you have and how you will spend it

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello, Neil. You went to university, didn't you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. University – the best days of my life. I made fantastic friends, went to great parties…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Did some work?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, yeah, I did some work, but probably not enough.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, the subject of today's show is student mental health. So, Neil, do you think you're looking back at your university days through rose-tinted spectacles ? And that means looking at a situation as being better than it really was.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, well, being out of your comfort zone means being in a situation that you aren't familiar with and which makes you feel nervous. Did you talk to anyone about your feelings, Neil? Did you get any counselling ? And that means professional help with personal or psychological problems.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What? No, not me. I'm one of those men who isn't good at talking about their feelings, Alice. I just felt a bit homesick that's all – I missed my friends and family. But let's move on, shall we! Why don't you ask me today's quiz question?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. So here it is: In a survey of students at Imperial College London, how many students said they suffered from high levels of stress or a mental health condition during their time at college? Was it… a) 1 out of 4? b) 2 out of 4? or c) 3 out of 4?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I'm going to go for c) 3 out of 4 because I do think that university life can be more stressful than people realize.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And stress means pressure or worry caused by a difficult situation. OK, we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on. Now in the UK, there has been a rise in students using counselling services.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Why's that, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, let's listen to Kirsty, a student at Exeter University, talking about why she has had problems. And here's a question for you while you listen: Did she enjoy her first days in college?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Kirsty McMurron, student at Exeter University No. The thing is… it… is a real balancing act. When I first got to university I don't think I'd really realized that I'd forgotten how to make friends you know, I'd been with the same school friends for seven years, and so I was trying to balance you know social success with academic success whilst learning how to look after myself at quite a young age. And I think that's the experience of a lot of young people. And people really struggle with it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What's a balancing act , Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It's where you try to give your attention to two or more things at the same time. So here, Kirsty is trying to balance making new friends with doing her academic work and learning to look after herself.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What does Kirsty mean when she says she's learning to look after herself?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, to look after someone means to protect or take care of someone – and in this case, Kirsty's learning to take care of herself – for example doing her own shopping and cooking.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, let's listen to Dr Ruth Caleb of the counselling service at Brunel University in London talking about what practical stuff students could learn before leaving for university that might make life easier for them.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Ruth Caleb, Head of the counselling service at Brunel University, London Certain things that I think it would be very very helpful for students to have put in place are an ability to do the practical things of life – to do the washing, to do the cleaning and so on – being able to cook. Budgeting is extremely important in university life. And also spending time on your own comfortably.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, that's excellent advice. I couldn't boil an egg when I arrived at uni.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh, really? Can you do it now, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Just about, just about.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yeah? Great. And what about budgeting ? This means planning how much money you have and how you will spend it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm still pretty bad at that. However, I am very good at spending time on my own comfortably.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, I can believe that – feet up, watching TV with a takeaway.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Takeaway, of course a takeaway cause I can't cook anything…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … not even an egg. You know me so well. So how about the answer to today's quiz question, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. I asked: In a survey of students at Imperial College London, how many said they suffered from high levels of stress or a mental health condition during their time at college? Was it… a) 1 out of 4? b) 2 out of 4? or c) 3 out of 4?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said c) 3 out of 4.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And you are correct – well done, Neil! The survey, completed by over a thousand students, also found that almost 70% of those that suffer from stress do so at least once a week, and 9% of students feel stressed constantly. Stressed means anxious and worried.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I feel anxious just thinking about all that stress. Can we hear today's words again?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: We certainly can. They are: through rose-tinted spectacles out of your comfort zone counselling homesick stress balancing act look after yourself budgeting stressed

transcript.author: Neil
